ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

TOA PAYOH MATERNAL AND CHILD HEALTH CLINIC
(Provision of outpatient services)


    1. Mr Cheong Yuen Chee asked the Minister for Health whether he will consider extending the facilities at the Toa Payoh Maternal and Child Health Clinic to provide outpatient services for the residents of Toa Payoh New Town.

    The Minister for Health (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, Sir, it is possible to introduce outpatient services in the Maternal and Child Health Clinic at Toa Payoh by using

Column: 1112

two rooms in this Clinic; one for the doctor's examination room and the other for the treatment room. I understand from the Member for Toa Payoh that at present the Maternal and Child Health Clinic in his constituency is underutilised because of a very successful family planning campaign. His suggestion that it should be converted into an outpatient services department is a good idea.

    The service will be introduced as soon as a medical officer is available and a few items of equipment are obtained. This can only be a temporary measure as the long term solution requires a much bigger facility for the population at Toa Payoh which is over 200,000. For this a three-doctor clinic is required.

Column: 1113



    At the moment, residents in Toa Payoh have a choice of consulting private practitioners within the housing estate or, alternatively, they may attend the nearby Government Outpatient Dispensaries, namely:- 

    Pegu Road Outpatient Dispensary;

    Bright Hill Drive Outpatient Dispensary;

    Upper Serangoon Road Outpatient Dispensary.

WORK PERMITS
(Policy and Number issued as at 28.2.77)


    2. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Labour what was the total number of Work Permits issued as at 28th February, 1977, and whether he is satisfied with the policy of issuing Work Permits to foreigners when there is still a large number of Singapore Citizens who are unemployed.

    The Minister of State for Labour (Mr Sia Kah Hui) (for the Minister for Labour): Mr Speaker, Sir, work permit holders constitute less than 10% of the approximately 870,400 employed persons in Singapore as 28th February, 1977.

    The hon. Member will recall that in his Budget Speech, the Finance Minister has said that the unemployment rate in 1976 continued to remain at a low level of 4.5%. As at the end of last year. 30,750 were on the unemployed register at the Employment Service of the Ministry. My Ministry found that the majority of those registered preferred white collar or soft jobs. For example, 13,069 or 58% of the 22,413 new registrants last year wanted white collar or soft jobs. We also discovered that many were choosy turning down blue collar work offered to them for reasons such as long distance from house, shift work and uncongenial work environment. Many of those registered, therefore, preferred to be jobless until something to their liking comes along.

    Since the late 60s the Republic underwent successful economic development. As a result, we experienced a tight labour situation. Given the shortage of skilled workers and the preference of Singaporeans for white collar

Column: 1114

and soft jobs, the Ministry had to issue liberally work permits to non-residents for work in the manufacturing and construction industries. In the case of white collar and soft jobs which Singaporeans are fond of, the Ministry was strict on the issue of work permits. The hon. Member will no doubt agree that the work permit policy adopted was necessary for our economic development.

HOUSING BOARD "HOME OWNERSHIP" SCHEME
(Number of flats sold)


    4. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for National Development and Communications (a) up to the latest convenient date, how many units of flats have been sold by the Housing and Development Board under the "Home-ownership" Scheme; (b) how many of those flats were purchased outright by the owners; and (c) how many of the owners used their Central Provident Fund contributions to purchase the flats either outright or on an instalment basis.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, as at 31st December 1976, a total of 110,591 units of flats have been sold under the "Home Ownership" Scheme. Of this, 7,685 units were purchased outright, while 63,148 units were purchased through the owners' CPF contributions either outright or on an instalment basis. The remaining 39,758 purchasers paid cash for down payment and balance of loan settled by monthly cash instalments.

HDB FLATS IN TIONG BAHRU ROAD AND BUKIT MERAH
(Lighting of corridors in the day)


    5. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for National Development and Communications, in view of inadequate sunlight reaching into the common corridors of the emergency type flats in Apartment Blocks 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5, Tiong Bahru Road

Column: 1116

and Apartment Blocks 108 and 109, Jalan Bukit Merah, because of their structure, if he will ask the Housing and Development Board to consider switching on the lights during the day time or providing means for more sunlight to be admitted into those flats.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Housing and Development Board will undertake to convert the above building blocks so that more sunlight can be admitted into the common corridors of these flats. However, as this would involve extensive demolition and alterations to the flats, the conversion has been programmed for the end of 1978 or early 1979.

    Generally, common corridors in HDB blocks are adequately illuminated in the evenings. During the day, there is sufficient natural daylight along the common corridors even in blocks of 1-room flats. However, in some of the blocks with long corridors the lighting may appear slightly inadequate in certain parts of the corridors during rainy days. The Area Officers in charge will investigate the need for turning on lights during the day, if found necessary.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the vacant site between the Toa Payoh Sports Stadium and the Swimming Complex is reserved for an indoor sports hall for indoor games, like badminton, basketball, volleyball, etc. It will be modelled along the lines of the

POINTS DEMERIT SYSTEM
(Number of driving licences suspended)


    7. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for National Development and Communications how many driving licences had been suspended under the Road Traffic (Demerit Points) Rules, 1975, as at 28th February, 1977, and if he is satisfied with the implementation of the Rules.

    The Senior Minister of State for Communications (Mr Ong Teng Cheong) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Points Demerit System was implemented on 1st March 1975 as a means to identify and remove careless, inconsiderate, reckless and dangerous drivers from the roads. Under this system, the driving licence of a driver will be suspended for a period up to a maximum of six months whenever he accumulates 12 demerit points or more within any period of 12 consecutive months.

    Since the introduction of the Points Demerit System in March 1975, a total of 84 driving licences had been suspended under the Road Traffic (Demerit Points) 28th February, 1977. Of this number, 40 driving licences are still under suspension. In addition, 1,922 drivers had been issued with warning notices during this period.

    Despite the implementation of the Points Demerit System and the various enforcement measures taken, the number of deaths caused by road accidents did not decline but remained at 288 in 1976. The number of accidents involving serious injury dropped by 8.8% from 2,674 in 1974 to 2,438 in 1975 but increased to 2,587 in 1976. To make the system more effective, the ROV and Traffic Police are presently studying the possibility of expanding the system to cover other traffic offences. The system will also be revised so

Column: 1118

that offences such as inconsiderate, careless and dangerous driving will carry more penalty points.

EMPLOYMENT PASSES
(Particulars as at 28.2.77)


    8. Mr Ang Nam Piau asked the Minister for Home Affairs and Education (a) how many persons had applied for Employment Passes up to 28th February, 1977; (b) how many applications have been approved; and (c) how many of the applicants who were granted Passes have applied for permanent residence; how many such applications have been approved and what were the reasons for the rejections.

    The Minister for Home Affairs and Education (Mr Chua Sian Chin): Mr Speaker, Sir, Employment Passes were issued as far back as 1959 and no records were kept in the earlier years. Prior to 1974 there was also no distinction between applications for new Employment Passes and applications for extension of Employment Passes. I will therefore give only the statistics from 1974 onwards.

    During the last three years up to 28th February, 1977, the Immigration Department received a total of 31,351 applications for new Employment Passes. Out of this total, 29,666 were approved. A total of 13,893 applications for extensions were also received of which 13,793 were approved.

    During the same period, a total of 1,919 Employment Pass holders applied for permanent residence in Singapore. 1,321 of these were approved. Those refused were mainly on grounds of:

    (i) lack of qualifications;

    (ii) lack of working experience; or

    (iii) the type of qualifications or skills possessed by the applicants being not in short supply in Singapore.

    The figures supplied do not include the Employment Passes granted to holders of work permits processed by the Ministry of Labour.

Column: 1119



    In case the Member may be wondering why the big gap between the number of people granted Employment Passes and the number of people applying for permanent residence, let me explain that the grant of permanent residence, being the first step towards the grant of citizenship, is more stringent than the grant of Employment Passes. It stands to reason, therefore, that not all Employment Pass holders are eligible to apply for permanent residence. Further, many of the Employment Pass holders are here to work only and are not interested to take up permanent residence. They, of course, do not apply for permanent residence. Those who are interested must generally have worked at least a few years in Singapore before they can apply.

ANG MO KIO NEW TOWN
(Construction of primary and secondary schools)


    9. Mr Yeo Toon Chia: To ask the Minister for Home Affairs and Education the number of primary and secondary schools to be constructed at Ang Mo Kio New Town and when they are expected to be completed.

    Mr Speaker: Mr Yeo Toon Chia.

    Mr Yeo Choo Kok: Question No. 9, Sir.

    The Senior Minister of State for Education (Mr Chai Chong Yii) (for the Minister for Home Affairs and Education): Mr Speaker, Sir, four primary schools and two secondary schools are scheduled for construction at Ang Mo Kio New Town. Construction on one primary school has begun and construction of another primary school and one secondary school will start soon. Further, two primary schools and one secondary school will be constructed in 1978. The schools constructed this year are expected to be completed before the end of next year, and those to be constructed in 1978 should be completed by 1979.

PRICE OF REFINED SUGAR


    10. Mr Yeo Toon Chia: To ask the Minister for Finance what are the reasons for the prevailing high price of refined sugar and whether it will be reduced in the near future.

    Mr Yeo Choo Kok: Mr Speaker, Sir, Question No. 10.

    The Minister for Finance (Mr Hon Sui Sen): Mr Speaker, Sir, sugar prices often fluctuate rapidly on the world market. To ensure uninterrupted supplies of raw sugar and to help maintain a stable domestic selling price for refined sugar, the Sugar Industry of Singapore has had to enter into long-term supply contracts. The current long-term contracts with Australia and Fiji, concluded towards the end of 1974, assured us of raw sugar supplies fully for 1975 - 77 and thereafter up to 85% of our domestic requirements until 1980. The contracted price at S$689 per metric tonne was then extremely favourable compared with the prevailing market price of about S$2,580 per metric tonne.

    Thus, the Sugar Industry of Singapore was able to maintain the domestic retail price of refined sugar at 75 cents per kati since 1974 to date. Otherwise, Singapore consumers would have had to pay as much as $2.25 for their kati of sugar if we had to buy on the open market at the peak of world price fluctuations. Taking the period between 1974 and now, the price paid by our consumers on the average is about 24 cents per kati lower than the average world price of white sugar.

    Members are no doubt aware that the price of raw sugar on the world market has fallen. The price of sugar paid under the current contract, however, has increased because of the escalation index tied to prices paid by the Australian sugar industry. The Sugar Industry of Singapore is at present trying to discuss with Australia some improvements in the terms of the contract. Apart from a lower price, it would be desirable that the new contract should enable us to diversify our sources of supply,

Column: 1121

especially to buy from other ASEAN countries.

    Since the Sugar Industry of Singapore is making a loss at prevailing prices, I have no proposals at present to ask SIS to make any revision of the price downwards, If necessary, I will consider whether the Sugar Industry of Singapore may be allowed adjustments to the domestic retail price of sugar when discussions are completed. However, any adjustments made will have to take a long term view of the market rather than to follow the erratic movements of world sugar prices.

    Mr Ivan Baptist (Potong Pasir): Mr Speaker, Sir, may I ask supplementary questions? First, why did we not attempt to re-negotiate the agreement very much earlier when we knew that world prices were dropping? Second, we had a price escalation clause. Why did we not negotiate for a price reduction clause? Third, I believe Malaysia retails their sugar at 65 cents a kati and we have the same sort of contract with the countries mentioned by the Hon. Minister. Why is that so? Why are we retailing our sugar at 75 cents a kati? Fourth, why did we not have the foresight to realise that the sugar prices could have dipped and so have a shorter term instead of that long-term contract?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is simple. The Sugar Industry of Singapore made a commercial judgment and decided that a long-term contract was desirable. Therefore, it entered into the terms of the present contract. At that time, of course, it was favourable. As I have said, the price was then very low. The escalation clause was built into the contract, because this was related to the cost of labour in Australia. The intention was that the long-term contract would enable Australia to expand their growing of sugar cane and that the price would be sufficient to enable their growers to pay their labour at the expected escalation in wages which would result in the following years. There was no possibility of a reduction in price downwards because of the nature of the contract.

Column: 1122



    The reason why we are paying 75 cents in Singapore instead of 65 cents as in Malaysia is that we kept the excise tax at a level which we have always been charging, that is, 10 cents, while the Malaysian Government thought it possible for them to waive the tax altogether. That is the reason for the difference between their price and our price. I think I have answered all the questions.

    Mr Ivan Baptist: A further supplementary question. Mr Speaker, Sir, what will be the effect on the price of sugar in Singapore as a result of the ban on saccharine in the United States?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I would think that the tendency would be upwards. Of course, there are other factors in the world sugar market which decide the price from time to time. Some of these are what prices are being negotiated, the effect on growers. that is, whether they grow more sugar cane, and also the effect of the new processes of making liquid sugar of a different kind, not cane sugar but from wheat and corn. All these have an effect on prices. If anyone can tell me whether the price is going upwards or downwards, I would be very pleased. I am sure the Sugar Industry of Singapore will also be very pleased if anyone can give a guaranteed forecast of prices over the next five years.

    Mr S. Dhanabalan (Kallang): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. If the Minister is satisfied that an increase in the price of sugar has to be allowed in order to enable SIS to cover its costs and make a marginal profit, would he consider a reduction in excise duty first, so that the price of such an essential commodity like sugar can be maintained at present levels?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, it is not the policy of the Singapore Government to reduce taxes in order to maintain prices I think we need our taxes and the revenues from them in order to satisfy the needs of our country. MPs, social services, economic development and other requirements.

    Mr Ho See Beng (Khe Bong): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. In

Column: 1123

view of the protection for the SIS, as a result of which the people of Singapore have to pay higher sugar prices, will the Minister not consider allowing the import of sugar?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, the answer is no. When the price went up to about $2,300 per metric tonne, I found no pressure in this House for an increase in sugar prices. I think the fact is that we have been able to maintain over the last three years a sugar price which has been entirely stable and I can see no reason why the public cannot pay this same price of 75 cents. We hope to be able to maintain this price because discussions are now going on with the Australians and if the parallel negotiations in Japan and Malaysia are favourable, I think we will also benefit to the same extent that concessions are made to these countries.

    Mr Ivan Baptist: Mr Speaker, Sir, would the Minister not like to see the consumers getting a cheaper price for their sugar, and this could be done by getting, say. the NTUC Welcome to import sugar from overseas?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I think the NTUC does not have any special expertise in importing cheaper sugar. Anyone can do it at world prices.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin (Jalan Kayu): Mr Speaker, Sir, a supplementary question. First, to what extent is the Singapore Government still interested in the Sugar Industry of Singapore? I am quite sure that the Government has still got a considerable equity interest in that company. Secondly, the Hon. Minister has gone to great lengths today to explain or to inform this House of the administrative decisions and actions taken by that company. This does seem to be in contradiction to what he has told this House a few days ago, that is, he is not accountable to this House for the administrative actions of all companies owned by Government, either wholly or partially-owned. Would he explain the apparent contradiction?

Column: 1124



    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, I will explain the apparent contradiction. In this particular case the agreement with Australia and Fiji was brought to the notice of the Government and we were asked to give a letter of awareness. As representing the Government of Singapore, I think I am also involved other than as a shareholder of the Sugar Industry of Singapore. In the case of the particular question as to what interest we have, we have 40% interest in the Sugar Industry of Singapore. So we are not in control of the Sugar Industry of Singapore except to the extent that 40% gives any particular shareholder control.

TAX ON RESIDENTIAL PROPERTY
(Particulars)


    11. Mr Ch'ng Jit Koon asked the Minister for Finance (a) what are the various rates of property tax levied on residential property; (b) how much revenue was collected in respect of each category in FY 76; and (c) what is the estimated revenue in respect of each category for FY 77.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore is divided into several zones for purposes of applying property tax assessment rates as prescribed under the Property Tax (Rates) Order, 1971. These zones are shown in the Property Tax Rate Plan which is available for inspection by members of the public in the Property Tax Office.

    Under this Plan, the highest assessment rate of 36% is levied on residential properties in the central city areas and in the southern islands comprising Sentosa, Sarong Island, Pulau Brani. Pulau Selegu and Pulau Hantu. Residential properties in the less developed areas are assessed at 27% while those in the rural areas, including all other surrounding islands, at 18%.

    All HDB owner-occupied flats purchased under the Board's Home Ownership Scheme are assessed at the concessionary rate of 23%. For other owner-occupied dwelling houses, concessionary assessment rates of 14%, 16%, 18%, 19%, 20% or 23% apply.

Column: 1125

Properties with annual value of less than $240. whether owner-occupied or not, are also subject to the same rates. The assessment rate of attap and wooden houses is $6 a year.

    Residential properties developed under approved urban redevelopment projects are assessed at a concessionary rate of 1 2% for 20 years before the full assessment rates applicable are imposed.

    For FY 76, the revenue collection for all properties, excluding contributions by statutory boards, is expected to reach $265 million, which includes a substantial amount of back tax. The estimated revenue collection for FY 77 for all properties, except statutory boards, is $230 million.

    No records of collection according to the different assessment rates for residential properties are kept. I regret, therefore, that I am unable to give the required breakdown.

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee (Toa Payoh): Sir, is the Minister aware that not all HDB dwellings get the concessionary rate of 23%? There are some HDB dwellings in Stirling Road, Queenstown, and St. Michael's estate which draw a rate of 36%.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: I believe that may be so. I am not quite informed of this particular instance. But I will look into it. Did the Member say HDB houses?

    Mr Cheong Yuen Chee: Yes, at 36%.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, in view of the steady drop in property values over the last few years, particularly in the last few months, would the Minister consider a downward revision in the rates of property tax?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, I assume the rates would also go down with the values and with the rents which are collected. Since this is a percentage of the annual value, and the annual value is based on rents, I assume there would be a reduction. I do not propose to reduce the rates as well as the annual values.

    Mr Hwang Soo Jin: Sir, the Minister used the word "assume". He said that he

Column: 1126

assumes the annual value, being based on the rental, therefore the annual value would come down. But I think the existing practice is that, quite independent of what the rented value of the property might be, the Property Tax Department lays its own assessment.

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, this may be due to the kind-heartedness of the Property Tax Department which does not always raise the annual values in accordance with the rents which property owners receive.

    Mr J. F. Conceicao (Katong): Neither do they reduce!

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: So if they are to be encouraged to base the annual values on rents, then I think they should raise it upwards as rapidly as they are expected to bring it downwards.

    Mr S. Dhanabalan: Sir, since the annual value already reflects the worth or value of a property. taking into account the type of property, the location and so on, would the Minister consider having a uniform rate of property tax for the whole of Singapore except in cases where specific exemptions or reductions are to be given for promotional purposes?

    Mr Hon Sui Sen: Sir, that is a consummation devoutly to be desired. I think the Property Tax Department and the Ministry of Finance have been trying for many years to rationalise the rates of property tax. If Members will have noticed when I read out the concessionary rates, it varies from 14%, 16%. 18%. 19%. 20% to 23%. I cannot myself imagine that a fine distinction can be drawn between properties which are only worthy of 14% and other properties which are worthy of 15% rates. Members will also notice that there are attap houses where the rate is $6 a year.

    I have been trying to revise the property rates to a uniform consistent rate. The difficulty is not to revise the rates downwards from the higher rates of up to 36%, as I think most Members would like me to do. The difficulty is really raising the other lower rates upwards, so that there will be a uniform rate
